metadata.case_name: Controller of Estate Duty v. Smt. Parvathi Ammal

facts.text: Shri R. Venkateswara Iyer died on April 6, 1957.
Smt. Parvathi Ammal, widow of deceased, filed statement as accountable person. Assistant Controller determined principal value of estate at Rs. 2,50,374, including Rs. 1,50,000 for Mayavaram Lodge.
Till March 11, 1955, deceased owned two buildings including Mayavaram Lodge and agricultural land. Carried on boarding and lodging business in Mayavaram Lodge and small chit business.
On March 11, 1955, deceased executed document described as partition deed, giving Mayavaram Lodge to his five sons in equal shares, retaining other house and agricultural land.

On June 25, 1955, deceased entered agreement with sons leasing Mayavaram Lodge back to him; continued boarding business. Profit and loss account showed Rs. 15,000 rent by book entries. Later sub-leased to third party.
Assistant Controller found property self-acquired, deed a settlement; donor took back property shortly after, got direct benefit; included Rs. 1,50,000.
Board of Direct Taxes dismissed appeal; gift effective on registration June 29, 1955 within 2 years (s.9); alternatively, donor not excluded from possession/enjoyment (s.10); not partition.
Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 215/1965 answered question partly for assessee, partly revenue: only value of right to possession/enjoyment as lessee passes; remanded for apportionment.

legal_issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the entire value of the property known as Mayavaram Lodge or any portion of its value is liable to be included in the principal value of the Estate of the deceased as property deemed to have passed on his death?

petitioner_arguments.text: Subsequent to deed of March 11, 1955 (assumed gift), donor took gifted property on lease; donees did not retain possession to entire exclusion of donor or benefit to him by contract or otherwise; entire value liable under s.10.
High Court erred; property gifted was entirety with all rights; not shorn of any rights; donor not excluded.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 10, Estate Duty Act, 1953; precedents like George Da Costa

respondent_arguments.text: Mayavaram Lodge transferred March 11, 1955 >2 years before death; lease long after, not associated; no special benefit; alternatively, partition of joint family property.
Only value of right to possession/enjoyment as lessee passes; donees retained ownership exclusively; proportionate value only.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 10, Estate Duty Act, 1953; Y.S. Mani v. Controller

respondent_arguments.text: Deed was partition; remand to determine.

court_reasoning.text: Deed of March 11, 1955 gifted entirety of Mayavaram Lodge with all rights; donees assumed possession/enjoyment; but donor took lease June 25, 1955; not retained to entire exclusion of donor/benefit by contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Both conditions of s.10 cumulative: immediate assumption and retention to exclusion.

court_reasoning.text: S.10 deems entire property taken under gift to pass if not excluded; not just right to possession; High Court erred in apportioning to lessee right only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Property is entirety; gift not shorn of rights unlike partnership cases.

court_reasoning.text: Not partition: self-acquired property, no evidence of joint family treatment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Board correctly found no waiver of separate rights.

court_reasoning.text: Precedents like John Lang, Chick confirm lease prevents exclusion even at full rent; Munro/Ramachandra apply only if gift shorn of rights (partnership).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Here, full ownership gifted, then leased back.

holdings.text: Entire value of Mayavaram Lodge liable to be included as property deemed to pass under s.10, Estate Duty Act, 1953.

precedents_cited.case_name: Y. S. Mani v. Controller of Estate Duty
precedents_cited.relevance: Donor retains interest pro tanto liable.

precedents_cited.case_name: George Da Costa v. Controller of Estate Duty Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: S.10 conditions cumulative; exclusion from property and benefit; entire property passes if not excluded.

precedents_cited.case_name: John Lang Ors. v. Thomas Prout Webb
precedents_cited.relevance: Lease back prevents exclusion even at full rent.

precedents_cited.case_name: Clifford John Chick Anr. v. Commissioner of Stamp Duties
precedents_cited.relevance: Partnership use prevents exclusion; irrelevant if full consideration.

precedents_cited.case_name: H. R. Munro ors. v. Commissioner of Stamp Duties
precedents_cited.relevance: Gift shorn of partnership rights; benefit referable to partnership not gift.

precedents_cited.case_name: Controller of Estate Duty Madras v. C. R. Ramachandra Gounder
precedents_cited.relevance: Gift of tenancy property to firm; benefit from partnership not gift.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rash Mohan Chatterjee Ors. v. Controller of Estate Duty West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: 'To the extent' means portion leased back liable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Controller of Estate Duty v. R. Kanakasabai Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: No reserved interest if not charged/enforceable.

statutes_cited.name: Estate Duty Act, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.64(1); s.9 for gifts <2 years; s.10 for non-exclusion of donor from possession/enjoyment/benefit.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court answer, held entire value of Mayavaram Lodge includible under s.10 as deemed to pass on death.
outcome.relief_granted: Question answered in favour of revenue: entire value liable.
outcome.costs: Appellant entitled to costs of appeal.

key_quotes.text: The crux of the section lies in two parts: 1 the donee must bona fide have assumed possession and enjoyment of the property... immediately upon the gift, and 2 the donee must have retained such possession and enjoyment... to the entire exclusion of the donor or of any benefit to him, by contract or otherwise.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Mayavaram Lodge as such shall be deemed to pass on the death of the deceased under section 10 of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The lease, however, gave to the donor possession and enjoyment of the land itself, which is a simple negation of exclusion, and brings the case within the statutory liability.
key_quotes.speaker: Issacs J. in John Lang (quoted)
